By EDITH PULA
University officials announced
today that the Rathskellar, a bar
and lounge area in the basement
of the Hopkins Union, was stolen
last night by what was described
as a "well- equipped and
ingenious" group of vandals.
The large-scale . theft
culminates nine months of
vandalism in the Rathskellar
which saw bar stools, beer mugs,
and decorations stolen.
The facility was apparently
wrenched loose from its steel
reinforced cement moorings late
last night, the officials said.
"They'd taken everything
else," observed Hopkins Union
Director Alan Sapakie. "I guess it
was just a matter of time before
they took the facility,in toto."
Sapakie and Security Director
George Weinbach speculated that
the vandals, probably
undergraduates, stole the facility
with a twin-rotary helicopter and
several long iron grappling hooks.
"It must've been a hell of a
noise when the son of a bitch
came loose," said Weinbach. "I'm
surprised none of our security
police were alerted by the
commotion."
Sapakie admitted that he was
in the Rathskellar at the time of
the larceny but asserted that the
operation was so well-executed
that he was not aware the facility
had been stolen until he "felt a
draft."
"I wish I could help you
but..." stuttered Sapakie.

Provost Harry Woolf expressed
the administration's shock at the
news of the theft. "We were
proud to have a facility of the
Rathskellar's demonstrated
efficiency and appeal in the
University community."
Student Council
President-elect Mike Lenardo
announced that the SC will
recommend to the administration
that an intensive search be held

to apprehend the vandals. "I
want something done about it,
because I do not like punitive
lenience, and besides I wrote a
great housing report."
Sapakie said that all social
programming in the Rathskellar
will be discontinued, in light of
the theft. "It [social
programming in a non-existent
facility] would probably not be a
good idea," he said.
Assistant Dean of Students
Dottie Lebo is currently
attempting to organize an
"amnesty night" for the return
of the Rathskellar.
"Whoever did this should
know that they can return that
lovely bar and lounge any time
without fear of reprisal," Lebo
noted. "They can bring the

Hopkins purchases 'Birds' for $12 million
By LAINY STEPHANS
In a surprise move late last
week, Hopkins purchased the
Baltimore Orioles baseball
franchise amid reports that
University officials plan to move
the team to Bologna.
The sale of the "Birds" to
Hopkins caught most
Baltimoreans off guard, since the
sale of the team to a group of
businessmen led by Bill Veeck
was considered almost completed
by most city officials.
Jerry Hoffberger's decision to
sell the team to Hopkins was
apparently spurred by the State
Legislature's failure to grant the
Veeck group a $4 million loan to
finance the purchase.
Vice President for Business
Management Robert Bowie said
that the team was purchased for
$12 million and would be
financed by borrowing money
from the University's
endowment. The endowment will

be replenished by the profits of
the baseball team, he stated.
Bowie also disclosed that "a
large part of the sum" will never
have to be paid, since Hoffberger
has agreed to "donate" some of
the money to the University, a
non-profit institution.
President Muller told reporters
yesterday that he is pleased with
the move, engineered primarily
by D.H. Harvey, Chairman of the
Board of Trustees as well as
chairman of the Board of
Maryland Natielal Park.
"As far as I know, we're the
first University anywhere to
make such a move," Muller said
proudly.
Muller informed the press that
Hopkins does not plan, much to
the ire of many local residents, to
keep the Orioles in Baltimore.
Instead, they will be moved, to
Bologna Italy, where Hopkins

Gutzman replacement protested
By PHIL LAZARUS
The New-Letter learned from
informed sources yesterday that
the University has replaced
George Gutzman, Assistant
Director of Personnel
Maintenance, who died last
November.
"Though we were happy to
have a man of Gutzman's
demonstrated ability on the
staff," explained Provost Harry
Woolf, "we feel that it [the
death] will have a negative effect
on his output potential."
The move has sparked
controversy from faculty
members and students
concerning the legitimacy of
replacing an employeee because
of death.
Ric Pfeffer', Professor of
Political Science, described the
replacement of Gutzman as "a
sloppy decision, full of
loop-holes."
"This is just one more
excuse," he continued, "that the
administration can use to get rid
of someone who isn't to their
liking."
One University employee, who

HEW guidelines for employment
quotas of dead people.
Theodore said yesterday that
she is "not quite exactly sure
what are the regulations
concerning the hiring of dead
people," but will examine them
closely to prevent any
disgruntled dead people from
taking "legal recourse against
Hopkins."
The sources also revealed that
the Student Council has launched
another committee to investigate
the University's policy of
replacing dead employees.
SC president-elect Mike
Lenardo, in an interview
yesterday, refused to
acknowledge the existence of
such a committee, but did state,
"I wrote a great housing report."
President Muller explained
that the policy of replacing dead
employees has been in existence
at Hopkins since at least the
Eisenhower tenure.
"As far as I'm concerned, it's

an historical accident. I didn't
institute the policy, but I see no
reason to change it," he said.
"The way I see things, our
policy is the best way to handle
it [death]," Muller added.
"Frankly, I think it's emminently
fair."
University Chaplain Chet
Wickwire said that he has written
a letter to the Board of Trustees
asking that they investigate the
University employee policy
regarding dead people.
"On the surface, it doesn't
really seem very fair to me," he
said.

By JAMES ALLEN
Dean of Arts and Sciences
eorge Owen announced
yesterday the ,appointment of
renowned children's author Dr.
Seuss . as Professor of Modern
Literature in the English
, Department.
Owen said that the
appointment, which is effective
this July, is part of a
'newly-initiated reorganization of
the English department.
"Dr. Seuss's appointment fills
'a need in our department," said
English Chairman Ronald
Paulson. "Usually we don't deal
with ancillary topics, but we are
.always wont to make
exceptions."
Paulson revealed that Seuss
will teach one undergraduate
course next semester before
taking a one-year leave of
absence.
Seuss specializes in modern
literature, fantasy writing, and
script-writing for television
,specials, and will offer graduate
seminars in "character creation."
Seuss's acc laimed works
include The Cat in the Hat, The
Cat in the Hat Comes Bac k The
Grinch That Stole Christmas, and
One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish,
Blue Fish.
Commenting on the
appointment, Provost Harry
Woolf noted, "We are pleased to
have a man of Seuss's
demonstrated ability on our
faculty."
Seuss, presently an Associate
Professor of Writing at Beloit
College, has been awarded a full
professorship with tenure by the
. Academic Council, Owen said.

Dr. George Benton will resign
his post as Homewood Vice
President in five days to become
the manager of the Bologna.Blue
Jays of Baseball's American
League, it was learned today.
The Bologna Blue Jays,
formerly the Baltimore Orioles,
were recently purchased ' by
Hopkins in an effort to increase
revenues for the coming fiscal
year. Former owner Jerry
Hoffberger said his decision to
sell the team to Hopkins was
based on his friendship with
Milton Eisenhower.
Commenting on his
appointment to the post, Benton
stated, "Being manager of the
Blue Jays should be more fun
than hiding Budget figures from
pesky students. If a guy without
a degree in meteorology like Earl
Weaver can handle the job..."
Benton continued,--There's no
way on God's green earth we
won't repeat as champions of the
American League. The Yankees
haven't got a chance."
Benton will be succeeded as
Homewood V.P. by Oriole
Catcher Earl Williams, who has
fallen out of the good graces of
present Oriole Manager, and is
looking for another job.
Immediately after his
appointment by President Muller,
Benton reportedly named his
coaching staff.
Larry Denton will coach first
base while former softball star

Jakie "foul out" Hall will leave
his post as Dean of Students to
handle the third base coaching
chores for the Blue Jays. Andrew
Savitz will fly in from his studies
in Oxford to handle the coaching
of the pitchers. Savitz
commented, "I know that I can
do the job as well as anybody.
George Bamberger [former
pitching coach of the Orioles]
has nothing on me. He wasn't
even a Rhodes Scholar was he?"
Benton refused to disclose if
any roster changes will follow
from the shakeup of the team.
"The roster list is confidential.
Besides Muller, as General

Manager of the team, told me I
wasn't supposed to say anything
about that to you guys."
Muller, who will continue to
serve as University President
while assuming the duties of the
Blue lays' General Manager,
stated that the Stadium on 33rd
street in Baltimore will be used
for lecture in Organic Chemistry
beginning Fall semester 1975.
He added, "I foresee no major
changes in the direction of the
University as resulting from all
this. We will continue to strive
for academic excellence, and
Andy Etchebarren will start
behind the plate."
